importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Demolition of the White House East Wing began on this date, marking the start of construction for the new ballroom project.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The construction period spans from the start of demolition in October 2025 to the expected completion of the new ballroom, with a projected end date of October 2026.

keyTakeAways: Demolition of the White House East Wing began on October 20, 2025, to make way for a new $200 million, 90,000-square-foot ballroom.

The ballroom, which will seat 650 people—more than three times the capacity of the East Room—will feature gold and crystal decor, gilded columns, and a coffered ceiling, aligning with the neoclassical theme of the White House.
President Donald Trump has publicly championed the project, stating it fulfills a 15-year ambition and will be funded by Trump and private donors.

The project is part of a broader effort to transform the White House grounds and architecture to reflect Trump’s aesthetic, including adding large flagpoles, paving over the Rose Garden, and decorating the Oval Office in gold.
Trump claimed there are no zoning restrictions, asserting that as president he has full authority to proceed with the construction.
The White House responded to criticism by referencing a 1950s reconstruction under President Truman, emphasizing that construction has always been part of the building’s evolution.
Renderings show the ballroom will have arched windows overlooking the south grounds and maintain architectural heritage while being modernized.
The project has sparked public debate over preservation versus modernization of a historic national landmark.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Demolition of the White House East Wing began on October 20, 2025, as President Donald Trump unveils a $200 million, 90,000-square-foot ballroom that will seat 650 people—more than three times the capacity of the existing East Room. The project, which fulfills a 15-year ambition, is funded by Trump and private donors and features a luxurious, gilded interior consistent with Trump’s aesthetic. The construction marks a significant alteration to the historic White House, with critics raising concerns over preservation. The White House defends the action by citing historical precedents, such as the Truman-era reconstruction, and emphasizes that modernization has always been part of the building’s evolution.
title: Demolition begins to replace White House East Wing with Trump’s ballroom
